My research  disagree with your presentation: Approximately 75 percent of the atmospheric oxygen is created by water based photosynthesis. Photosynthesis operates effectively in the temperature range of 15 to 30 degrees Centigrade. Approximately on 25 percent of atmospheric oxygen is created by land based photosynthesis ( but as deforestation increases this percentage is trending downward).  Depending on the type of plant life photosynthesis stops between 28 to 32 degrees Centigrade.  There is no other significant form of oxygen generation other than photosynthesis by carbon based plant life.  Certain plant life  operate at higher temperatures because they buffer the energy captured in the first cycle of photosynthesis called Photosynthesis I/KERB cycle and process the long term storage of the energy in the 2nd cycle of photosynthesis called Photosynthesis II/Dark cycle when the temperature drops.  The KREB cycle operates only when there is enough  light/photons to capture.  The Dark cycle operates  only when the temperature is within a  proper temperature ranges (Dark cycle enzyme operate only is a particular temperature range).  Since Earth surface is  6/7 water based ... water based photosynthesis has been the dominant oxygen producer and hence carbon dioxide scrubber  of Earth... Medieval warming and cooling periods.

Approximately 1,100 years ago during the 9th century the climate entered what is called the Medieval Warming period. During this warming period the global climate warmed enough that a large part of Greenland was actually green and was colonized by the Viking people who grew crops and tended herds of grazing animals (Hancock and Brian 613-617). Agriculture in Europe thrived as the growing season grew longer and crops could be grown further north (Hancock and Brian 666). Humanity's standard of living steadily improved for centuries as the food supply continued to increase with the warming climate. Global warming continued until sometime in the 13th or 14th century when the Medieval Warming period transformed into the Medieval Cooling Period (also know as the dark ages). When the climate started cooling, agriculture production started to fall and there was not enough food to feed the people or their herd animals. The Vikings were forced to abandon their Greenland colony and turn to raiding to survive (Wallace 16-24). In Europe, people starved and diseases were rampant. A plague was responsible for the death of nearly 25% of the known population of the earth (Hancock and Brian 613-617).

Hancock, Paul L., Brian J. Skinner. The Oxford Companion to The Earth. Chicago: Oxford University Press, 2000.

Wallace, Birgitta. “Viking Farewell.” Beaver December 2006/January 2007 Volume 86 Issue 6 Page 16-24. 8 April 2009.

That is when the world was just starting to warm up from the depth of the Medieval cooling period. That way they do not have to explain that modern temperatures are just now getting back to the height of the Medieval warming period. Makes it much more dramatic that way.

Thats the fun part of climate change. It's not just one thing, its multiple things that stack on each other. Increased co2 causes the global temperature to rise. That causes the ice caps to melt faster and not return to the same size that they were the year prior. The decreased size of the ice caps means that less of the suns light is reflected off of the ice. Also contributing to the hastening phase of melting ice caps. The ice contains trapped co2 as well, which makes things even worse. Then, when the ice recedes. It uncovers land that was previously permanently frozen, permafrost. This doesn't just make the land unstable (causing buildings built there to also become unstable) it also releases further co2 and methane that was trapped in the ground, making the issue even worse.


It's not some linear thing, the temperature slowly rising due to humans pumping co2 into the atmosphere. It's exponential. Compounding factors, some we haven't even thought of yet, will continue to make this worse at a faster and faster rate. We are the disease, this is a fever that mother nature is having to expunge us.

It doesn't have to be this way though. We just need to take action, preferably 20 or so years ago. But today is far better than tomorrow. Every day we wait is hundreds, maybe even thousands of years off of the lifespan of the human race. This isn't new, we have known this for a long time. People just *refuse to listen*. They care about money, profits. Over the continuation of the human race. "What about China and India?" What about them? They need to make changes as well. But we don't have direct control over what they do. So let's change what we have the power to change, and hope that they follow suit. They only produce co2 to meet the demands of the international consumer. If we all decide to make a change, they will have no choice but to follow us into the future.

It's useful to think of two carbon sources: fossil carbon and the biogenic carbon cycle. Every plant that takes up atmospheric carbon will release it again after its short life and decomposition.  This is the biogenic cycle. It was enough to keep the atmospheric carbon reasonably stable until we found a source of long-term-locked-away carbon and unleashed it into the atmosphere. Now that THAT genie is out of the bottle, all the plants/algaes etc can only partially buffer it because it's now subject to the 'short turnover' biogenic cycle.

There are at least five potential tipping points that if any were to happen, it's game over: 1️⃣ Blue ocean event, ice-free arctic ocean, due 2035 under status quo greenhouse gas emissions.
2️⃣ Methane time bomb, mass release from permafrost or deep ocean methane clathrates. 3️⃣ Rainforest dryout, turns to savannah, starts releasing more carbon dioxide than it intakes.
4️⃣ Oceanic conveyor stoppage, freshwater from Greenland's melting ice sheet halts the turnover. 5️⃣ Critical species extinction, if the bees go, we lose half our food, worldwide mass famine.
PS, the scary part is that only one of five has a known timeline; the rest could just happen. https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2021/01/climate-change-sudden-cataclysmic-need-act-fast

So, in summary:

~Plants absorb CO2 via photosynthesis and respirate O2.
~Photosyntheis has a max temperature that it stops functioning at.
~Respiration has a higher max temperature that it stops functioning at.
~Plants will respirate C02.
~Amazon Rainforest and Russia & Canada Taiga forests, 40% of carbon sinks, will be emitting that much in CO2 by at least 2040 and are not likely to evolve to adapt to hotter temperatures in two decades.
~However, sea plants, which absorb 40% of global CO2 emissions, may absorb more CO2 and respirate over time.

A lot to panic over, but what can we do?
~Expand on green energy; solar and wind is a start, but nuclear and fission may have to pick up the load.
~Expand on carbon-capture technology, both natural (olivine rock) and artificial (carbon-capturing plants and CO2-absorbing materials).
~Expand on lab-grown meat and divert subsidies from meat plants and towards lab-grown meat and other GMOs. If need be, starting with a way for cows to reduce Methane emissions may be a good transition step.
~Implement more vertical farming for reduction of land use, and possibly convert the land to natural wildlife.
~Implement a carbon tax to sway people away from using fossil fuels, as well as giving out less subsidies towards fossil fuels.

I remember from physics that liquids absorb gas inversely proportional to temperature. The hotter a liquid, the less gas it can absorb. The ocean currently eats up a ton of carbon, but it has a limit, and as we heat the ocean that limit goes down. Reach the limit, and we could create a feedback loop of the ocean dumping CO2 which warms the atmosphere which warms the ocean which dumps CO2. I’m sure there is a bottom to this loop, after all we’ve had high concentrations of CO2 in the distant past, but this kind of shock would not be pretty.

The soil? If that was true there would be huge craters under every tree. No, plants get their mass like all other forms of life: Carbon. So unless plants suddenly decide to stop growing in hotter temperatures they're still going to take carbon out of the atmosphere.

How do they grow if they throw more carbon out than in. Won’t they just shrink at that point?

Sure these small things can, for a period, start churning the carbon in the sugar into CO2 faster, but it’ll run out.

These micro-organisms can either put that sugar into CO2 so slow that it accumulates slowly. Or that they’re reducing the amount present in the soil...
But then they can still only consume those 2 parts max.
